fields.contents: The Kukui Cup residence hall energy competition is a blend of real world and virtual world activities. In the real world, participants attend events, engage in real-world activities like geocaching, scavenger hunts, and artistic/musical events, win prizes, and most importantly, modify their energy-related behaviors. In the virtual world of the Kukui Cup web application, participants earn points, achieve badges, increase their energy literacy through readings and videos, and use social networking mechanisms to engage with friends about the event. Our hope is that this combination of real and virtual activities complement and reinforce each other. The blending of real and virtual worlds has been explored in other "serious games" such as Urgent/Evoke.
fields.title: What is the Kukui Cup?

fields.contents:
Motivation
One of the goals of the Kukui Cup is to learn more about the factors which help people to make sustained, positive changes to their energy behaviors.
Kinds of data collected
In order to accomplish this goal, we wish to collect and analyze data about your participation in the competition. This data takes two forms:

    Data collected from your interactions with this website. We will collect data about the things you do while logged in to this website, such as your activities, goals, and commitments. This helps us to understand which of these tasks are interesting and helpful.
    Data gathered through interviews and questionnaires. We will contact a subset of participants to request a short interview and/or to fill out an online questionnaire. This data will help us to understand more about the strengths and weaknesses of our approach. 

Privacy
No identifying information about you will be made available in any research publications resulting from this study.

Note that as part of your participation in the competition, information such as your "public commitments" will be made available to others via mechanisms such as the Kukui Cup "wall" in your home page. If you choose to enable Facebook integration, then public commitments and activities will be transmitted to Facebook. However, such identifying information will not be made available in future research publications.
If you do not wish to participate
Your participation in this study is voluntary. If you decide you do not wish to participate in this study at any time, please contact Philip Johnson (johnson@hawaii.edu, 956-3489, POST 307, University of Hawaii). We will remove your data from all analyses.

You can decline to participate in this study but still participate in the Kukui Cup. Your decision to participate or not has no impact on your ablity to win prizes or participate in events associated with the competition.
fields.title: Terms and Conditions

fields.contents: The Kukui Cup consists of two types of competitions: individual competitions and lounge competitions.
fields.title: Competitions

fields.contents: In a lounge competition, pairs of floors compete as a unit. Each dorm is divided into five groups consisting of floors 3-4, 5-6, 7-8, 9-10, and 11-12. To win in the lounge competition, your lounge must reduce its energy consumption more than other groups. To simplify things, whenever we refer to "floor" in this competition, we really mean "pair of floors".
fields.title: Lounge Energy Competition

fields.contents: In an individual competition, you compete to accumulate the most "Kukui Nut" points by performing various actions, including activities, goals, and commitments. To win in the individual competition, you simply have to accumulate the most Kukui Nut points.
fields.title: Individual Kukui Cup Points

fields.contents:
The competition will be held for three weeks starting in October, 2011. The official start date will be announced soon.

To provide multiple chances to win, the competition is divided into two week-long "rounds" as well as an overall "grand prize" round.

After the first week of competition, the winners of "Round 1" will be announced based upon those individuals who accumulated the most Kukui Nut points and those floors who reduced their energy consumption the most.

After the second week of competition, the winners of "Round 2" will be announced. Round 2 winners are based only on data from the second week of the competition.

After the third week of competition, the "Grand Prize" winners will be announced. The Grand Prize winners are based upon all three weeks of data.

fields.contents: Some of the activites in the Smart Grid Game involve you to watch a video, attend an event, or do certain activities around the dorms. To do an activity, go to the Get Nutz page and find an activity that you would like to perform. After performing an activity, there will be either questions, code inputs, or image uploads that you will have to provide to prove that you have done the activity. After an Admin approves the activity you done, you will get your points!!!
fields.title: Performing Activities

fields.contents: Some of the activities in the Smart Grid Game involve commitments, and you can engage in up to five commitments at any one time. We notice that you are committed to just "N" commitments. Why not go for all five and earn the super-committed badge for energy conservation? To make a commitment, go to the Get Nutz page and find <5 - N> more commitments that you are comfortable carrying out. Remember that a commitment only lasts for five days and then have to renew it if you want to continue the commitment. You get points for each commitment you complete for a five day period.
fields.title: Making Commitments

fields.contents: One of the most challenging games in the Kukui Cup is the Daily Energy Goal. We have collected data on your lounge's energy usage since the beginning of the semester, and for this quest, you need to work with your lounge mates to reduce your lounge's overall usage by 5%. Each day that your lounge meets or beats this conservation goal, you and everyone else in your lounge will earn Kukui Cup points. To set a conservation goal, start by going to the Go Low page by clicking on the energy meter icon at the top of this page. Once there, find out your lounge's current consumption for today and see if it's above or below the goal. Then do whatever you can personally to minimize your energy consumption for the remainder of today, and encourage your lounge mates to do the same. See the Go Low page for suggestions on what to do. If you're successful, your lounge will have used less energy than the goal by midnight tonight, and everyone in your lounge will get awarded Kukui Cup points!

fields.title: Award Categories and Prizes

fields.contents:
In the event that two or more individuals (or floors) are tied for the most points, then the timestamp associated with the final goal, commitment, or activity associated with the individuals (or floors) will be used to break the tie. In other words, the individual (or floor) who got to their final point total first will be declared the winner. Under the remote possibility that the final timestamps are equal, a coin toss will be used to decide the winner.

Given that energy consumption is measured down to a fraction of a watt-hour, we do not anticipate that any floor could tie with respect to their consumption. In case that this does occur, a coin toss will be used to decide the winner.
fields.title: In the Event of Ties

fields.contents: The baseline is based on the average usage from the months before the competition. I.E. the months when the students have moved into the dorms and have situated themselves within the dorms.
fields.title: How do you figure out the baseline?

fields.contents:
A plug load is the energy consumed by any electronic device that's plugged into a socket.

Currently, the meters in the residence halls only monitor the energy used by the wall outlets ("plug loads") on floors 3 through 12 (where residence rooms are located).

fields.contents: The Raffle Game provides a different way to win prizes, a way that does not require you to be the number 1 ranked lounge or person. Each time you accumulate 25 Kukui Cup points, you receive 1 raffle ticket, which you can allocate into a drawing for one or more of the prizes in the raffle. Your chances of winning that prize correspond to the percentage of tickets allocated to that prize that you contributed. You can change your ticket allocation at any time during a round. The more points you earn, the more tickets you receive, and the higher your chances of winning prizes in the raffle.

fields.contents: **Welcome to the Smart Grid Game!** <p/> Each square on the grid indicates an activity, commitment, event, or excursion you can participate in. Completing activities earns you points. <p/> The lock icon indicates the activity is locked, but you can click on the lock icon to see how to unlock it. Often you can unlock an activity by completing other activities on the grid. <p/> Numbers on the grid indicate how many points you will earn for completing the activity. <p/> Once an activity is completed, a little check tag will display on the top-left corner of the grid square. <p/> If you see a little exclamation mark tag on a square instead, that means there is something about this activity need your attention. Two common reasons the mark are: there was a problem with your verification submission (such as an answer to a question) so you need to review the reply and resubmit to get your points, or an event or excursion is over and now you can claim the rest of your points.
fields.title: Smart Grid Game

fields.contents: Welcome to the Energy Goal Game. <p/> If the stop light is red, it means you are currently exceeding your energy consumption goal. At midnight, if the stop light is green, your lounge will be rewarded points for consume less than your predefined consumption goal.
